title: Formula Interface for {ggplot2}
text: several excellent graphics packages provided R. ggformula package currently builds one , ggplot2, provides different user interface creating plots. interface based formulas (much like lattice interface) use chaining operator (|>) build complex graphics simpler components. ggformula graphics designed several user groups mind: beginners want get started quickly may find syntax ggplot2() bit offputting, familiar lattice graphics, wanting able easily create multilayered plots, prefer formula interface, perhaps familiar use functions like lm() use mosaic package numerical summaries. basic template creating plot ggformula , equivalently, plottype describes type plot (layer) desired (points, lines, histogram, etc., etc.), mydata data frame containing variables used plot, formula describes /variables used. example, bivariate plot, formula take form y ~ x, y name variable plotted y-axis x name variable plotted x-axis. (also possible use expressions can evaluated using variables data frame well.) first form tempate useful simple plots multi-layered plots different layers use different data. second form useful multi-layered plots plots many arguments. simple example:   “kind graphic” specified name graphics function. ggformula data graphics functions names starting gf_, intended remind user formula-based interfaces ggplot2: g ggplot2 f “formula.” Commonly used functions include gf_point() scatter plots gf_line() line plots (connecting dots scatter plot) gf_density() gf_dens() gf_histogram() gf_dhistogram() gf_freqpoly() display distributions quantitative variable gf_boxplot() gf_violin() comparing distributions side--side gf_counts() bar-graph style depictions counts. gf_bar() general bar-graph style graphics function names generally match corresponding function name ggplot2, although gf_counts() simplified special case geom_bar(), gf_dens() alternative gf_density() displays density plot slightly differently gf_dhistogram() produces density histogram rather count histogram. gf_ functions can create coordinate axes fill one operation. (ggplot2 nomenclature, gf_ functions create frame add layer, one operation.) happens first gf_ function chain. subsequent gf_ functions, new layers added, one “top ” previous layers. marks plot glyph. Every glyph graphical attributes (called aesthetics ggplot2) tell draw glyph. plot, obvious attributes x- y-position: ’ve told R put mpg along y-axis hp along x-asis, clear plot. point also attributes, including color, shape, size, stroke, fill, alpha (transparency). didn’t specify example, gf_point() uses default values – case smallish black filled-circles. gf_ functions, specify non-position graphical attributes using additional arguments function. Attributes can set constant value (e.g, set color “blue”; set size 2) can mapped variable data expression involving variables (e.g., map color sex, sex determines color groupings) Attributes set mapped using additional arguments. adding argument form attribute = value sets attribute value. adding argument form attribute = ~ expression maps attribute expression attribute one color, shape, etc., value constant (e.g. "red" 0.5, appropriate), expression may general expression can computed using variables data (although often better create new variable data use variable instead --fly calculation within plot). following plot, instance, use cyl determine color carb determine size dot. Color size mapped cyl carb. legend provided show us mapping done. (Later, can use scales control precisely mapping done – colors sizes used represent values cyl carb.) also set transparency 50%. gives value alpha glyphs layer.  ggformula allows --fly calculations attributes, although default labeling plot often better create new variable data frame. examples , since three values carb, easier read graph tell R treat cyl categorical variable converting factor (string). Except labeling legend, two plots . second example, see ggformula works well data tranformations using |>.   plots, specify x-position y-position calculated x-values. Histograms, densityplots, frequency polygons examples. illustrate, ’ll use density plots, ideas apply gf_histogram(), gf_freqpolygon() well. Note one-variable density graphics, variable whose density calculated goes right tilde, position reserved x-axis variable.     Several plotting functions include additional arguments modify attributes individual glyphs control aspect plot. case, adjust can used increase decrease amount smoothing.   learn ggformula, see longer version vignette available https://www.mosaic-web.org/ggformula/. version include sections Adjusting position (stack, dodge, etc.) Faceting (coordinated subplots) Plot labeling (including using labels attached data labelled expss packages) Chaining create complext (multi-layer) plots Using jitter transparency deal overplotting Additional plot types Using positions stats Visualizing functions Maps Plotting distributions Global plot adjustments (themes, labels, etc.) Horizontal geoms
code: gf_plottype(formula, data = mydata) mydata |> gf_plottype(formula) library(ggformula) gf_point(mpg ~ hp, data = mtcars) mtcars |> gf_point(mpg ~ hp) gf_point(mpg ~ hp, color = ~cyl, size = ~carb, alpha = 0.50, data = mtcars) library(dplyr) gf_point(   mpg ~ hp,   color = ~ factor(cyl),   size = ~carb,   alpha = 0.75,   data = mtcars ) mtcars |>   mutate(cylinders = factor(cyl)) |>   gf_point(mpg ~ hp, color = ~cylinders, size = ~carb, alpha = 0.75) data(penguins, package = "palmerpenguins") gf_density(~bill_length_mm, data = penguins) gf_density(~bill_length_mm, fill = ~species, alpha = 0.5, data = penguins) # gf_dens() is similar, but there is no line at bottom/sides and the plot is not fillable gf_dens(~bill_length_mm, color = ~species, alpha = 0.7, data = penguins) # gf_dens2() is like gf_dens() but is fillable gf_dens2(   ~bill_length_mm,   fill = ~species,   data = penguins,   color = "gray50",   alpha = 0.4 ) # less smoothing penguins |>   gf_dens(~bill_length_mm, color = ~species, alpha = 0.7, adjust = 0.25) #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_density()`). # more smoothing penguins |> gf_dens(~bill_length_mm, color = ~species, alpha = 0.7, adjust = 4) #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_density()`).

title: Formula Interface for {ggplot2}
text: “kind graphic” specified name graphics function. ggformula data graphics functions names starting gf_, intended remind user formula-based interfaces ggplot2: g ggplot2 f “formula.” Commonly used functions include gf_point() scatter plots gf_line() line plots (connecting dots scatter plot) gf_density() gf_dens() gf_histogram() gf_dhistogram() gf_freqpoly() display distributions quantitative variable gf_boxplot() gf_violin() comparing distributions side--side gf_counts() bar-graph style depictions counts. gf_bar() general bar-graph style graphics function names generally match corresponding function name ggplot2, although gf_counts() simplified special case geom_bar(), gf_dens() alternative gf_density() displays density plot slightly differently gf_dhistogram() produces density histogram rather count histogram. gf_ functions can create coordinate axes fill one operation. (ggplot2 nomenclature, gf_ functions create frame add layer, one operation.) happens first gf_ function chain. subsequent gf_ functions, new layers added, one “top ” previous layers.

title: Formula Interface for {ggplot2}
text: marks plot glyph. Every glyph graphical attributes (called aesthetics ggplot2) tell draw glyph. plot, obvious attributes x- y-position: ’ve told R put mpg along y-axis hp along x-asis, clear plot. point also attributes, including color, shape, size, stroke, fill, alpha (transparency). didn’t specify example, gf_point() uses default values – case smallish black filled-circles. gf_ functions, specify non-position graphical attributes using additional arguments function. Attributes can set constant value (e.g, set color “blue”; set size 2) can mapped variable data expression involving variables (e.g., map color sex, sex determines color groupings) Attributes set mapped using additional arguments. adding argument form attribute = value sets attribute value. adding argument form attribute = ~ expression maps attribute expression attribute one color, shape, etc., value constant (e.g. "red" 0.5, appropriate), expression may general expression can computed using variables data (although often better create new variable data use variable instead --fly calculation within plot). following plot, instance, use cyl determine color carb determine size dot. Color size mapped cyl carb. legend provided show us mapping done. (Later, can use scales control precisely mapping done – colors sizes used represent values cyl carb.) also set transparency 50%. gives value alpha glyphs layer.  ggformula allows --fly calculations attributes, although default labeling plot often better create new variable data frame. examples , since three values carb, easier read graph tell R treat cyl categorical variable converting factor (string). Except labeling legend, two plots . second example, see ggformula works well data tranformations using |>.
code: gf_point(mpg ~ hp, color = ~cyl, size = ~carb, alpha = 0.50, data = mtcars) library(dplyr) gf_point(   mpg ~ hp,   color = ~ factor(cyl),   size = ~carb,   alpha = 0.75,   data = mtcars ) mtcars |>   mutate(cylinders = factor(cyl)) |>   gf_point(mpg ~ hp, color = ~cylinders, size = ~carb, alpha = 0.75)

title: Interactive graphics with {ggformula}
text: {ggiraph} package provides number interactive geoms. {ggformula} makes available via gf_*_interactive() functions. Interactive geoms provide several types interaction. easy tooltips using tooltip = restyling elements upon hover selection multiple elements linking items across multiple plots custom javascript applied clicking graphical element onclick =. type interaction can customized behavior style. Although discussed , {ggiraph} transforms graphics reactive objects, making various events selections available shiny apps. Interactive geoms provide two new aesthetics can used used help identify provide additional information individual points sets points. tooltip provides text (HTML) displayed tooltip. data_id provides identifier selection. previous example, data_id unique identifier points. next example, data_id identifies groups cars (number cylinders). hover text identifies car name number cylinders. Many graphics – bar graphs, histograms, boxplots, density plots, etc. – built original data transformation data. Understanding role data transformations computed statistics scales can important creating graphics. example tooltips allow us see many items represented segment stacked bar plot. after_stat() default, map variables, mapping uses original data provide layer. layer created summarised data (bars defined counts, boxplots defined 5-number summaries, densities density plots, etc.), option mapping summarising statistic applied. ’s after_stat() . don’t column named count data, stat used gf_bar() gf_bar_interactive() computes counts (additional things), storing counts column called count, available statistic computed. tooltip = ~ after_stat(count) creates tooltip variable count calculated. examples like , can handy know data available summarising statistic applied. can inspect layer_data().1 things notice: one row bars. access new columns provide information bars: count, ymin, ymax, xmin, xmax. computed stat. can see tooltip data_id also appear . longer access columns like color (mapped x values 1, 2, 3, …) cut (instead fill shows actual color used fill bars). values computed scales third stage data transformation. Warning Note previous graphic, count displayed hovering count single segment, segments change color. latter determined data_id, after_stat(count) know . desireable, need refine either tooltip data_id make match. See Section 1.3.1. several ways get finer control highlited information appears tooltip hover. Sometimes better summarise data creating graphic. gf_col_interactive() similar gf_bar_interacive(), designed work data already summarised. use data_id limits hover highlighting one bar segment (defined cut color). omit data_id previous example, still get hover text, bar segment hovering change color. Alternatively, might prefer let gf_bar_interactive() take care data summarising us, still finer control highliting tooltip text. stage() mentioned , ggplot2 graphics built, data goes sequence transformations. can mapping three stages along way. start: process begins original data provide. default, mapping happens. after_stat: starting data transformed statistic (stat) computes summaries data. after_scale: after_stat data transformed scales compute specific positions, colors, etc. used. use stage() allows us map quantity different values different stages process. example, start = glue::glue("color: {color}; cut: {cut}"), creates column named tooltip contains text identifying color cut diamond. after_stat = glue::glue("cut: {tooltip}; count = {count}")) uses tooltip value created start stage create new tooltip column stat calculated count available. encountered stage() , can learn documentation stage(). Interactive scales can used inside gf_refine() generate interactive guides (legends, axes, etc.). , interactive scales interesting. key selections can turned reactive values use things like shiny apps. See https://www.ardata.fr/ggiraph-book/shiny.html. Interactive faceting requires three things: use gf_facet_wrap_interacive() gf_facet_grid_interactive(), place gf_facet_wrap() gf_facet_grid(); use interactive labeller (labeller = gf_labeller_interactive()) create labels; theme enables facet text /strips interactive. Warning Now added facets, situation counts displayed individual bar segment, even though segments facets also highlited. faceting partitions data stat applied. required facet knows size bar segments display. Note PANEL group columns layer data. {ggiraph} provides 3 intereactive elements use interactive themes: element_text_interactive() element_rect_interactive() element_line_interactive() drop-replacements non-interactive counterparts. can used gf_theme() add interactive theme elements individual plot, done previous example; can used set_girafe_defaults(); can included custom theme functions. {ggformula} provides theme_facets_interactive() adding interactive elements faceting theme choice. ’ll return example Section 2 see improve hover interaction. use {patchwork} arrange multiple plots grid, selecting points one plot highlight . know JavaScript, can create click actions interactive plot elements passing JavaScript executed onclick. section include just two example uses JavaScript. example , use open webpage related information.
code: library(ggformula) theme_set(theme_bw()) data(mtcars) mtcars2 <- mtcars |>   tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "carname")  cars_scatter <-   mtcars2 |>   gf_point_interactive(     wt ~ drat,     color = ~mpg,     tooltip = ~carname, # show carname when hovering on a point     data_id = ~carname, # unique identifier -- selection is a single point     hover_nearest = TRUE,     size = 3   )  # to display the graph with interactive compontents enabled, use # gf_girafe() to convert it to an HTML widget.  gf_girafe(cars_scatter) cars_scatter_tooltip <-   mtcars2 |>   gf_point_interactive(     qsec ~ disp,     tooltip = ~ glue::glue("{carname} ({cyl} cylinders)"),     data_id = ~cyl,     size = 3,     hover_nearest = TRUE   )  gf_girafe(cars_scatter_tooltip) data(diamonds) diamonds_bargraph <-   diamonds |>   gf_bar_interactive(     ~color,     fill = ~cut,     tooltip = ~ after_stat(count),     data_id = ~ as.character(cut)   )  diamonds_bargraph |> gf_girafe() diamonds_bargraph |> layer_data() |> head(3) #>   count prop x flipped_aes      fill data_id PANEL group tooltip    y ymin ymax #> 1   163    1 1       FALSE #440154FF    Fair     1     1     163 6775 6612 6775 #> 2   224    1 2       FALSE #440154FF    Fair     1     2     224 9797 9573 9797 #> 3   312    1 3       FALSE #440154FF    Fair     1     3     312 9542 9230 9542 #>   xmin xmax colour linewidth linetype alpha width #> 1 0.55 1.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 #> 2 1.55 2.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 #> 3 2.55 3.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 library(dplyr) diamonds |>   group_by(color, cut) |>   summarise(count = n()) |>   gf_col_interactive(     count ~ color,     fill = ~cut,     tooltip = ~ glue::glue("color: {color}, cut: {cut}, count: {count}"),     data_id = ~ glue::glue("{cut} - {color}")   ) |>   gf_girafe() #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'color'. You can override using the #> `.groups` argument. diamonds |>   group_by(color, cut) |>   summarise(count = n()) |>   gf_col_interactive(     count ~ color,     fill = ~cut,     tooltip = ~ glue::glue("color: {color}, cut: {cut}, count: {count}")   ) |>   gf_girafe() #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'color'. You can override using the #> `.groups` argument. diamonds_bargraph_2 <-   diamonds |>   gf_bar_interactive(     ~color,     fill = ~cut,     tooltip = ~ stage(       start = glue::glue("color: {color}; cut: {cut}"),       after_stat = glue::glue("{tooltip}; count = {count}")     ),     data_id = ~ glue::glue("{cut} -- {color}"),     size = 3   ) #> Warning in (function (mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "count", position = #> "stack", : Ignoring unknown parameters: `size` diamonds_bargraph_2 |>   gf_girafe() diamonds_bargraph_3 <-   diamonds_bargraph |>   gf_refine(     scale_fill_viridis_d_interactive(       begin = 0.1,       end = 0.7,       option = "D",       data_id = function(breaks) as.character(breaks),       tooltip = function(breaks) glue::glue("break: {as.character(breaks)}")     )   )  diamonds_bargraph_3 |>   gf_girafe() diamonds_bargraph_4 <-   diamonds_bargraph_3 |>   gf_theme(     strip.text = element_text_interactive(),     strip.background = element_rect_interactive()   ) |>   gf_facet_wrap_interactive(     ~clarity, # or vars(clarity)     interactive_on = "both",     ncol = 2,     labeller = gf_labeller_interactive(       tooltip = ~ paste("this is clarity", clarity),       data_id = ~clarity     )   )     diamonds_bargraph_4 |> gf_girafe() diamonds_bargraph_4 |> layer_data() |> slice_sample(n=4) #>   count prop x flipped_aes      fill data_id PANEL group tooltip    y ymin ymax #> 1   608    1 3       FALSE #43BF71FF   Ideal     3    31     608  608    0  608 #> 2    32    1 6       FALSE #482576FF    Fair     4     6      32 1169 1137 1169 #> 3   202    1 7       FALSE #1E9C89FF Premium     4    28     202  434  232  434 #> 4   209    1 7       FALSE #1E9C89FF Premium     3    28     209  452  243  452 #>   xmin xmax colour linewidth linetype alpha width #> 1 2.55 3.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 #> 2 5.55 6.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 #> 3 6.55 7.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 #> 4 6.55 7.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 diamonds_bargraph_3 |>   gf_theme(theme_facets_interactive(theme_minimal())) |>   gf_facet_wrap_interactive(     ~clarity, # or vars(clarity)     interactive_on = "both",     ncol = 2,     labeller = gf_labeller_interactive(       tooltip = ~ paste("this is clarity", clarity),       data_id = ~clarity     )   ) |>   gf_girafe() library(patchwork)   cars_scatter_2 <-   mtcars2 |>   gf_point_interactive(     disp ~ qsec,     color = ~mpg,     tooltip = ~carname,     data_id = ~carname,     hover_nearest = TRUE,     size = 3   )  gf_girafe(cars_scatter / cars_scatter_2) mtcars2 |>   gf_point_interactive(     wt ~ drat,     color = ~mpg,     data_id = ~carname,      onclick = ~glue::glue('alert("Here is some info for {carname} ...")'),     size = 3   ) |>     gf_girafe() mtcars2 |>   gf_point_interactive(     wt ~ drat,     color = ~ mpg,     data_id = ~ carname,      tooltip = ~ carname,     onclick = ~ glue::glue('window.open("https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search={carname}")'),     size = 3   ) |>     gf_girafe()

Warning Note previous graphic, count displayed hovering count single segment, segments change color. latter determined data_id, after_stat(count) know . desireable, need refine either tooltip data_id make match. See Section 1.3.1. several ways get finer control highlited information appears tooltip hover. Alternatively, might prefer let gf_bar_interactive() take care data summarising us, still finer control highliting tooltip text. stage() mentioned , ggplot2 graphics built, data goes sequence transformations. can mapping three stages along way. start: process begins original data provide. default, mapping happens. after_stat: starting data transformed statistic (stat) computes summaries data. after_scale: after_stat data transformed scales compute specific positions, colors, etc. used. use stage() allows us map quantity different values different stages process. example, start = glue::glue("color: {color}; cut: {cut}"), creates column named tooltip contains text identifying color cut diamond. after_stat = glue::glue("cut: {tooltip}; count = {count}")) uses tooltip value created start stage create new tooltip column stat calculated count available. encountered stage() , can learn documentation stage().
code: data(diamonds) diamonds_bargraph <-   diamonds |>   gf_bar_interactive(     ~color,     fill = ~cut,     tooltip = ~ after_stat(count),     data_id = ~ as.character(cut)   )  diamonds_bargraph |> gf_girafe() diamonds_bargraph |> layer_data() |> head(3) #>   count prop x flipped_aes      fill data_id PANEL group tooltip    y ymin ymax #> 1   163    1 1       FALSE #440154FF    Fair     1     1     163 6775 6612 6775 #> 2   224    1 2       FALSE #440154FF    Fair     1     2     224 9797 9573 9797 #> 3   312    1 3       FALSE #440154FF    Fair     1     3     312 9542 9230 9542 #>   xmin xmax colour linewidth linetype alpha width #> 1 0.55 1.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 #> 2 1.55 2.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 #> 3 2.55 3.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 library(dplyr) diamonds |>   group_by(color, cut) |>   summarise(count = n()) |>   gf_col_interactive(     count ~ color,     fill = ~cut,     tooltip = ~ glue::glue("color: {color}, cut: {cut}, count: {count}"),     data_id = ~ glue::glue("{cut} - {color}")   ) |>   gf_girafe() #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'color'. You can override using the #> `.groups` argument. diamonds |>   group_by(color, cut) |>   summarise(count = n()) |>   gf_col_interactive(     count ~ color,     fill = ~cut,     tooltip = ~ glue::glue("color: {color}, cut: {cut}, count: {count}")   ) |>   gf_girafe() #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'color'. title: Interactive graphics with {ggformula}
text: several ways get finer control highlited information appears tooltip hover. Sometimes better summarise data creating graphic. gf_col_interactive() similar gf_bar_interacive(), designed work data already summarised. use data_id limits hover highlighting one bar segment (defined cut color). omit data_id previous example, still get hover text, bar segment hovering change color. Alternatively, might prefer let gf_bar_interactive() take care data summarising us, still finer control highliting tooltip text. stage() mentioned , ggplot2 graphics built, data goes sequence transformations. can mapping three stages along way. start: process begins original data provide. default, mapping happens. after_stat: starting data transformed statistic (stat) computes summaries data. after_scale: after_stat data transformed scales compute specific positions, colors, etc. used. use stage() allows us map quantity different values different stages process. example, start = glue::glue("color: {color}; cut: {cut}"), creates column named tooltip contains text identifying color cut diamond. after_stat = glue::glue("cut: {tooltip}; count = {count}")) uses tooltip value created start stage create new tooltip column stat calculated count available. encountered stage() , can learn documentation stage().

title: Interactive graphics with {ggformula}
text: Interactive scales can used inside gf_refine() generate interactive guides (legends, axes, etc.). , interactive scales interesting. key selections can turned reactive values use things like shiny apps. See https://www.ardata.fr/ggiraph-book/shiny.html.
code: diamonds_bargraph_3 <-   diamonds_bargraph |>   gf_refine(     scale_fill_viridis_d_interactive(       begin = 0.1,       end = 0.7,       option = "D",       data_id = function(breaks) as.character(breaks),       tooltip = function(breaks) glue::glue("break: {as.character(breaks)}")     )   )  diamonds_bargraph_3 |>   gf_girafe()

Warning Now added facets, situation counts displayed individual bar segment, even though segments facets also highlited. faceting partitions data stat applied. required facet knows size bar segments display. Note PANEL group columns layer data.
code: diamonds_bargraph_4 <-   diamonds_bargraph_3 |>   gf_theme(     strip.text = element_text_interactive(),     strip.background = element_rect_interactive()   ) |>   gf_facet_wrap_interactive(     ~clarity, # or vars(clarity)     interactive_on = "both",     ncol = 2,     labeller = gf_labeller_interactive(       tooltip = ~ paste("this is clarity", clarity),       data_id = ~clarity     )   )     diamonds_bargraph_4 |> gf_girafe() diamonds_bargraph_4 |> layer_data() |> slice_sample(n=4) #>   count prop x flipped_aes      fill data_id PANEL group tooltip    y ymin ymax #> 1   608    1 3       FALSE #43BF71FF   Ideal     3    31     608  608    0  608 #> 2    32    1 6       FALSE #482576FF    Fair     4     6      32 1169 1137 1169 #> 3   202    1 7       FALSE #1E9C89FF Premium     4    28     202  434  232  434 #> 4   209    1 7       FALSE #1E9C89FF Premium     3    28     209  452  243  452 #>   xmin xmax colour linewidth linetype alpha width #> 1 2.55 3.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 #> 2 5.55 6.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 #> 3 6.55 7.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9 #> 4 6.55 7.45     NA       0.5        1    NA   0.9

title: Interactive graphics with {ggformula}
text: {ggiraph} provides 3 intereactive elements use interactive themes: element_text_interactive() element_rect_interactive() element_line_interactive() drop-replacements non-interactive counterparts. can used gf_theme() add interactive theme elements individual plot, done previous example; can used set_girafe_defaults(); can included custom theme functions. {ggformula} provides theme_facets_interactive() adding interactive elements faceting theme choice. ’ll return example Section 2 see improve hover interaction.
code: diamonds_bargraph_3 |>   gf_theme(theme_facets_interactive(theme_minimal())) |>   gf_facet_wrap_interactive(     ~clarity, # or vars(clarity)     interactive_on = "both",     ncol = 2,     labeller = gf_labeller_interactive(       tooltip = ~ paste("this is clarity", clarity),       data_id = ~clarity     )   ) |>   gf_girafe()

title: Interactive graphics with {ggformula}
text: know JavaScript, can create click actions interactive plot elements passing JavaScript executed onclick. section include just two example uses JavaScript. example , use open webpage related information.
code: mtcars2 |>   gf_point_interactive(     wt ~ drat,     color = ~mpg,     data_id = ~carname,      onclick = ~glue::glue('alert("Here is some info for {carname} ...")'),     size = 3   ) |>     gf_girafe() mtcars2 |>   gf_point_interactive(     wt ~ drat,     color = ~ mpg,     data_id = ~ carname,      tooltip = ~ carname,     onclick = ~ glue::glue('window.open("https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search={carname}")'),     size = 3   ) |>     gf_girafe()

title: Interactive graphics with {ggformula}
text: can customize interactive features plots one two ways: Setting options = list( ... ) call gf_girafe(), Using set_girafe_defaults( ... ). either case replace ... calls one following: fonts = list(...) opts_sizing = opts_sizing(...) opts_tooltip = opts_tooltip(...) opts_hover = opts_hover(...) opts_hover_key = opts_hover_key(...) opts_hover_inv = opts_hover_inv(...) opts_hover_theme = opts_hover_theme(...) opts_selection = opts_selection(...) opts_selection_inv = opts_selection_inv(...) opts_selection_key = opts_selection_key(...) opts_selection_theme = opts_selection_theme(...) opts_zoom = opts_zoom(...) opts_toolbar = opts_toolbar(...) Girafe animations produced SVG (scalable vector graphics) format. can customize SVGs appear using CSS (cascading style sheets). many functions utilities help us create correct CSS. options require user provide CSS string semi-colon separated key-value pairs, key-value pairs separated colons. many options can avoid writing CSS directly using helper functions. style many interactive elements determined character string containing CSS styling. CSS declaration includes property name associated value. Property names values separated colons name-value pairs always end semicolon. Spaces can added around delimeters improve readability. example color:gray; text-align:center;". Common CSS properties include: color: color points, etc. stroke: color lines, text, etc. background-color: background color text fill: fill color points, rectangles, etc. border-style, border-width, border-color: border properties rectangles, can combined border: 5px solid red; width, height: size (tooltip, example) padding: space around content opacity: opacity (number 0 1) Color keys Notice names keys setting color vary among various kinds elements. make things confusing, text elements stroke fill. Text often look better stroke removed, unless large enough substantial space within stroke. Don’t include curly braces familiar CSS, might tempted wrap CSS string curly braces. gf_girafe() takes care adding , don’t include string. Use opts_hover style hovered data elements, opts_hover_inv style non-hovered data elements, opts_hover_key style hovered guide elements. Common CSS properties styling elements include fill: background color stroke: color stroke-width: border width r: circle radius opacity: opacity (number 0 1) can use opacity improve interactive facets. still leaves room improvement hover option affecting strip rectangle strip text. Sometimes need finer control gets styled css. example, using interactive facets gf_label_interactive(), interactive elements include text rectangles, may wish style differently. girafe_css() provides finer control. css argument provides starting point can overridden subsequent arguments: text, point, line, area (used rects, polygons, paths), image. another example, time using gf_label_interactive(). Styling hovering guide element (part legend key) handled opts_hover_key() way used opts_hover(). can also style non-selected elements opts_hover_inv(). Use low opacity non-selected elements make highlighted elements stand . use low opacity non-hovered elements can used highlight selected elements. opts_tooltip() three arguments determining position tooltip: use_cursor_pos – logical indicating whether tooltip position relative cursor position (default) upper left corner plot. offx, offy – number pixels offset tooltip base position. set use_fill = TRUE, fil color tooltip match color plot element associated . downside use_fill = TRUE Depending color scheme, may find hard find text color works well different fill colors. can enable panning zooming choosing value max greater 1 opts_zoom(). can set options globally using set_girafe_defaults() Warning Notice using opts_tooltip() options argument gf_girafe() changes offx, offy, use_cursor_pos, also causes css revert package defaults rather session defaults set.
code: diamonds_bargraph_3 |>   gf_theme(theme_facets_interactive(theme_minimal())) |>   gf_facet_wrap_interactive(     ~clarity, # or vars(clarity)     interactive_on = "both",     ncol = 2,     labeller = gf_labeller_interactive(       tooltip = ~ paste("this is clarity", clarity),       data_id = ~clarity     )   ) |>   gf_girafe(     options = list(       opts_hover("fill:red; opacity: 0.5")     )   ) diamonds_bargraph_3 |>   gf_theme(theme_facets_interactive(theme_minimal())) |>   gf_facet_wrap_interactive(     ~clarity, # or vars(clarity)     interactive_on = "both",     ncol = 2,     labeller = gf_labeller_interactive(       tooltip = ~ paste("this is clarity", clarity),       data_id = ~clarity     )   ) |>   gf_girafe(     options = list(       opts_hover(         css = girafe_css(           css = "fill:red; opacity:0.7; stroke:black; stroke-width:3px;",           text = "stroke:none; fill:white; opacity:0.9;"         )       )     )   ) mtcars2[1:6, ] |>   gf_label_interactive(qsec ~ disp, label = ~carname, data_id = ~carname) |>   gf_girafe(     options = list(       opts_hover(         css = girafe_css(           css = "fill:yellow;",           text = "stroke:none; fill:red;"         )       )     )   ) mosaicData::Weather |>   gf_line_interactive(     high_temp ~ date,     color = ~city,     show.legend = FALSE,     tooltip = ~city,     data_id = ~city   ) |>   gf_facet_wrap_interactive(     ~year,     ncol = 1,     scales = "free_x",     labeller = gf_labeller_interactive(       data_id = ~year,       tooltip = ~ glue::glue("This is the year {year}")     )   ) |>   gf_theme(theme_facets_interactive()) |>   gf_girafe(     options = list(       opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.2;"),       opts_hover(css = "stroke-width:2;", nearest_distance = 40),       opts_tooltip(use_cursor_pos = FALSE, offx = 0, offy = -30)     )   ) cars_scatter |>   gf_girafe(     options = list(       opts_tooltip(offx = 0, offy = -30, use_cursor_pos = FALSE)     )   ) diamonds_bargraph_3 |>   gf_girafe(     options = list(       opts_tooltip(         use_fill = TRUE,         offx = 0,         offy = 0,         use_cursor_pos = FALSE,         css = "border: 2px solid black; color: aliceblue; border-radius: 4px; padding: 6px;"       )     )   ) cars_scatter |>   gf_girafe(     options = list(opts_zoom(max = 5))   ) set_girafe_defaults(   # set colors for   opts_hover = opts_hover(     css = "fill:yellow;stroke:black;stroke-width:3px;r:10px;"   ),   opts_hover_inv = opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.5"),   # allow zooming/panning up to 4x size   opts_zoom = opts_zoom(min = 1, max = 4),   opts_tooltip = opts_tooltip(     css = "padding: 2px; border: 4px solid navy; background-color: steelblue; color: white; border-radius: 8px"   ),   opts_sizing = opts_sizing(rescale = TRUE),   opts_toolbar = opts_toolbar(     saveaspng = FALSE,     position = "bottom",     delay_mouseout = 5000   ) )  cars_scatter |>   gf_girafe() cars_scatter |>   gf_girafe(     options = list(       opts_tooltip(offx = 0, offy = -25, use_cursor_pos = FALSE)     )   )

title: Interactive graphics with {ggformula}
text: can set options globally using set_girafe_defaults() Warning Notice using opts_tooltip() options argument gf_girafe() changes offx, offy, use_cursor_pos, also causes css revert package defaults rather session defaults set.
code: set_girafe_defaults(   # set colors for   opts_hover = opts_hover(     css = "fill:yellow;stroke:black;stroke-width:3px;r:10px;"   ),   opts_hover_inv = opts_hover_inv(css = "opacity:0.5"),   # allow zooming/panning up to 4x size   opts_zoom = opts_zoom(min = 1, max = 4),   opts_tooltip = opts_tooltip(     css = "padding: 2px; border: 4px solid navy; background-color: steelblue; color: white; border-radius: 8px"   ),   opts_sizing = opts_sizing(rescale = TRUE),   opts_toolbar = opts_toolbar(     saveaspng = FALSE,     position = "bottom",     delay_mouseout = 5000   ) )  cars_scatter |>   gf_girafe() cars_scatter |>   gf_girafe(     options = list(       opts_tooltip(offx = 0, offy = -25, use_cursor_pos = FALSE)     )   )

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: several excellent graphics packages provided R. ggformula package currently builds one , ggplot2, provides different user interface creating plots. interface based formulas (much like lattice interface) use chaining operator (|>) build complex graphics simpler components. ggformula graphics designed several user groups mind: beginners want get started quickly may find syntax ggplot2() bit offputting, familiar lattice graphics, wanting able easily create multilayered plots, prefer formula interface, perhaps familiar use functions like lm() use mosaic package numerical summaries. basic template creating plot ggformula , equivalently, plottype describes type plot (layer) desired (points, lines, histogram, etc., etc.), mydata data frame containing variables used plot, formula describes /variables used. example, bivariate plot, formula take form y ~ x, y name variable plotted y-axis x name variable plotted x-axis. (also possible use expressions can evaluated using variables data frame well.) first form tempate useful simple plots multi-layered plots different layers use different data. second form useful multi-layered plots plots many arguments. simple example:   “kind graphic” specified name graphics function. ggformula data graphics functions names starting gf_, intended remind user formula-based interfaces ggplot2: g ggplot2 f “formula.” Commonly used functions include gf_point() scatter plots gf_line() line plots (connecting dots scatter plot) gf_density() gf_dens() gf_histogram() gf_dhistogram() gf_freqpoly() display distributions quantitative variable gf_boxplot() gf_violin() comparing distributions side--side gf_counts() bar-graph style depictions counts. gf_bar() general bar-graph style graphics function names generally match corresponding function name ggplot2, although gf_counts() simplified special case geom_bar(), gf_dens() alternative gf_density() displays density plot slightly differently gf_dhistogram() produces density histogram rather count histogram. gf_ functions can create coordinate axes fill one operation. (ggplot2 nomenclature, gf_ functions create frame add layer, one operation.) happens first gf_ function chain. subsequent gf_ functions, new layers added, one “top ” previous layers. marks plot glyph. Every glyph graphical attributes (called aesthetics ggplot2) tell draw glyph. plot, obvious attributes x- y-position: ’ve told R put mpg along y-axis hp along x-asis, clear plot. point also attributes, including color, shape, size, stroke, fill, alpha (transparency). didn’t specify example, gf_point() uses default values – case smallish black filled-circles. gf_ functions, specify non-position graphical attributes using additional arguments function. Attributes can set constant value (e.g, set color “blue”; set size 2) can mapped variable data expression involving variables (e.g., map color sex, sex determines color groupings) Attributes set mapped using additional arguments. adding argument form attribute = value sets attribute value. adding argument form attribute = ~ expression maps attribute expression attribute one color, shape, etc., value constant (e.g. "red" 0.5, appropriate), expression may general expression can computed using variables data (although often better create new variable data use variable instead --fly calculation within plot). following plot, instance, use cyl determine color carb determine size dot. Color size mapped cyl carb. legend provided show us mapping done. (Later, can use scales control precisely mapping done – colors sizes used represent values cyl carb.) also set transparency 50%. gives value alpha glyphs layer.  ggformula allows --fly calculations attributes, although default labeling plot often better create new variable data frame. examples , since three values carb, easier read graph tell R treat cyl categorical variable converting factor (string). Histograms, densityplots, frequency polygons examples. illustrate, ’ll use density plots, ideas apply gf_histogram(), gf_freqpolygon() well. Note one-variable density graphics, variable whose density calculated goes right tilde, position reserved x-axis variable.     Several plotting functions include additional arguments modify attributes individual glyphs control aspect plot. case, adjust can used increase decrease amount smoothing.   fill color group aesthetics mapped variable, default behavior lay group-wise densities top one another. behavior also available using position argument. Using value "stack" causes densities laid one top another. makes overall height stack represent density across groups, can difficult discern shape distribution individual groups. value "fill" produces conditional probability graphic.   Similar commands can constructed gf_histogram() gf_freqpoly(), note color, fill, active attribute frequency polygons. ’s also rarely good overlay histograms top one another – better use density plot frequency polygon application. ggplot2 system allows make subplots — called “facets” — based values one two categorical variables. done chaining gf_facet_grid() gf_facet_wrap(). functions use formulas specify variable(s) used faceting.     alternative syntax uses | separate faceting information main part formula. another example using weather data. redundant use y color attributes temperature makes easier compare across facets.   case, either facet year, allows x-scale freely adjusted column don’t much unnecessary white space. can latter using scales argument gf_facet_grid().   Usually plot labels reflect expression mapped given attribute. previous example, colorbar legend labeled “avg temp (F)” even though variable name avg_temp. Weather data set labeled. ggformula detect labels use plots. can use set_variable_labels() add custom labels variables data frame.1    adding labels data, can ensure consitent labeling across several plots. also possible modify labels just one plot. can done three ways: can use arguments like xlab, ylab, title; can use gf_labs() function (arguments like x, y, title, etc.); can use gf_relabel() function.     Notice gf_labs() gf_relabel() take different approaches labeling. gf_labs() refers labels role plot whereas gf_relabel() refers variables data set uses new labels wherever variable appears. useful. gf_labs() provides access additional labels (title, subtitle, caption, etc.), easier mistakenly create plot label doesn’t match true content plot. gf_relabel() deals labels associated variables, label guaranteed match variable matter variable used within plot. Often useful overlay multiple layers onto single plot. can done chaining |>, “” operator magrittr. data argument can omitted new layers uses data first layer chain. following plot illustrates histograms frequency polygons related.  2-d density plot can augmented scatterplot.  Sometimes many points scatter plot obscure one another. ggplot2 system provides two easy ways deal : translucency jittering. Use alpha make points semi-translucent. Using gf_jitter() place gf_point() move plotted points reduce overlap. Jitter transparency can used together well.    Box whisker plots show distribution quantitative variable function categorical variable. formula used gf_boxplot() quantitative variable left tilde. Alternatively, create new categorical variable puts quantitative values one different bins. gf_violin() gf_sina() provide two alternatives box whisker plots.   Ridge plots can useful displaying multiple density plots compactly.   Two-dimensional plots density also left right component formula.    ggplot2 system offers two ways connect points. gf_line() ignores order points data, draws line going left right. gf_path() goes point point according order data. forms can use color group aesthetic indicate groups points connected. ’s example gf_line() useful. begin scatter plot showing number live births US day 1978.  Can interesting pattern explained weekday/weekend effect? Converting line plot coloring day week highlights pattern makes easy spot unusual days.  example look used gf_path() data set already sorted date. general, gf_path() gf_line() produce different results. plots , first connects days chronologically (data sorted date) second order low temperature.   layers require two attributes. Typically happens glyphs layer complex objects made using multiple layers, belong together conceptually. Examples include gf_pointrange() – plots dot flanked line segment. gf_linrange() – like gf_pointrange() without point. gf_errorbar() – vertical error bars. gf_errorbarh() – horizontal error bars. gf_ribbon() – band line line . Often used depict sort estimate uncertainty measurement prediction, can used represent data correct form. use gf_linerange() gf_ribbon() indicate high low temperatures New York first months 2013.   position_dodge(), position_jitter(), position_jitterdodge() can used adjust positions glyphs placed. Jittering adds random noise can useful many observations value. Dodging moves groups glyphs fixed difference make easier distinguish groups.  stat transformation applied data plot generated. Several plots seen made use stats. gf_histogram() uses stat_bin() bin data count number observations bin. equivalent  gf_boxplot() uses stat_boxplot() compute five-number summary boxplot based. gf_violin(), gf_density(), gf_density2d() use stats compute sequence points along estimated density. points, raw data used create plot. gf_sina() uses estimated density jitter points.   also number stats can used show functional relationship two variables. gf_smooth() plots model fit using lm(), glm(), gam(), loess(), MASS::rlm(). gf_lm() gf_smooth() method set lm() plots least squares regression line. gf_spline() plots spline fit data.    Confidence prediction bands can added well.  Mostly, stats selected default just ones need. sometimes useful select different stat. stat_summary() stat_summary_bin() stats particularly useful respect. stats use function aggregate unique values x bins x values save user needing data transformation manually. default function applied group mean_se(), computes mean (mean plus minus one standard error) makes simple create “interaction plot”.   two values computed mean_se() available (starting ggplot2 version 2.3) stat(ymin) stat(ymax).   Custom functions can used defining fun.y, fun.ymin, fun.ymax, single function fun.data returns data frame variables named y, ymin, ymax.  ggformula provides two way plot functions: gf_function() gf_fun(). differ primarily one specifies function plotted. gf_function() requires (vectorized) function one variable. gf_fun() requires formula describing y-values computed x-values. used first layer, limits x-axis must specified.   Prior ggplot2 version 2.3, basic maps created using gf_polygon().  Starting ggplot2 version 2.3, direct support shape files. allows row data frame contain geometry information region single column. also better support overlaying information multiple shape files.  ggformula adds additional plot options ggplot2 Average shifted histograms can created gf_ash(). plots average height histograms bin width. ASH plots often work well larger bin widths might use individual histogram.   gf_dist() can used create plots discrete continuous distributions.      distribution parameters plot attributes name, two ways avoid name collision:   ggformula also provides interface MASS::fitdistr() fitting distributions data displaying resulting pdf.  number things may want entire plot – adjusting labels, colors, fonts, etc. ggformula provides wrappers ggplot2 functions chaining syntax can used.   convenience, modifications can also made directly original function call:  geoms ggplot2 can either horizontal vertical direction. Often ggplot2 correctly determine orientation intended. , set orientation = 'x' orientation = 'y' explicitly set direction geom.

carb, alpha = 0.50, data = mtcars) library(dplyr) gf_point(mpg ~ hp,  color = ~ factor(cyl), size = ~ carb, alpha = 0.75, data = mtcars) mtcars |>    mutate(cylinders = factor(cyl)) |>    gf_point(mpg ~ hp,  color = ~ cylinders, size = ~ carb, alpha = 0.75) data(penguins, package = "palmerpenguins")    gf_density( ~ bill_length_mm, data = penguins) gf_density( ~ bill_length_mm,  fill = ~ species,  alpha = 0.5, data = penguins) # gf_dens() is similar, but there is no line at bottom/sides and the plot is not fillable gf_dens( ~ bill_length_mm, color = ~ species,  alpha = 0.7, data = penguins) # gf_dens2() is like gf_dens() but is fillable gf_dens2( ~ bill_length_mm, fill = ~ species, data = penguins,           color = "gray50", alpha = 0.4) # less smoothing penguins |> gf_dens( ~ bill_length_mm, color = ~ species, alpha = 0.7, adjust = 0.25)   #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_density()`). # more smoothing penguins |> gf_dens( ~ bill_length_mm, color = ~ species, alpha = 0.7, adjust = 4)      #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_density()`). penguins |>    gf_density( ~ bill_length_mm, fill = ~ species, color = NA, position = "stack") penguins |>    gf_density( ~ bill_length_mm, fill = ~ species, color = NA, position = "fill",                adjust = 2) penguins |> bill_depth_mm) |>    gf_facet_grid( species ~ .) penguins |>    gf_density_2d(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm) |>    gf_facet_grid(island ~ species) penguins |>    gf_density_2d_filled(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm,                         show.legend = FALSE) |>    gf_facet_wrap(island ~ species) Weather |>    gf_ribbon(low_temp + high_temp ~ date | city ~ year, alpha = 0.3) Weather |>    gf_linerange(low_temp + high_temp ~ date | city ~ year, color = ~ avg_temp) |>   gf_refine(scale_colour_gradientn(colors = rev(rainbow(5)))) Weather |>    gf_ribbon(low_temp + high_temp ~ date | city ~ ., alpha = 0.3) Weather |>    gf_linerange(low_temp + high_temp ~ date, color = ~ avg_temp) |>   gf_refine(scale_colour_gradientn(colors = rev(rainbow(5)))) |>   gf_facet_grid(city ~ year, scales = "free_x") get_variable_labels(Weather) #> $city #> NULL #>  #> $date #> NULL #>  #> $year #> NULL #>  #> $month #> NULL #>  #> $day #> NULL #>  #> $high_temp #> [1] "high temp (F)" #>  #> $avg_temp #> #> [1] "precipitation" #>  #> $events #> [1] "events" KF <- KidsFeet |>    set_variable_labels(     length = "length (cm)",      width = "width (cm)",     domhand = "dominant hand",     biggerfoot = "bigger foot"   )  KidsFeet |>    gf_point(width ~ length, color = ~domhand) KF |>   gf_point(width ~ length, color = ~domhand) Penguins <- penguins |>   set_variable_labels(     species = "Species", code: gf_plottype(formula, data = mydata) mydata |> gf_plottype(formula) library(ggformula) gf_point(mpg ~ hp, data = mtcars) mtcars |> gf_point(mpg ~ hp)

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: “kind graphic” specified name graphics function. ggformula data graphics functions names starting gf_, intended remind user formula-based interfaces ggplot2: g ggplot2 f “formula.” Commonly used functions include gf_point() scatter plots gf_line() line plots (connecting dots scatter plot) gf_density() gf_dens() gf_histogram() gf_dhistogram() gf_freqpoly() display distributions quantitative variable gf_boxplot() gf_violin() comparing distributions side--side gf_counts() bar-graph style depictions counts. gf_bar() general bar-graph style graphics function names generally match corresponding function name ggplot2, although gf_counts() simplified special case geom_bar(), gf_dens() alternative gf_density() displays density plot slightly differently gf_dhistogram() produces density histogram rather count histogram. gf_ functions can create coordinate axes fill one operation. (ggplot2 nomenclature, gf_ functions create frame add layer, one operation.) happens first gf_ function chain. subsequent gf_ functions, new layers added, one “top ” previous layers.

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)

Every glyph graphical attributes (called aesthetics ggplot2) tell draw glyph. plot, obvious attributes x- y-position: ’ve told R put mpg along y-axis hp along x-asis, clear plot. point also attributes, including color, shape, size, stroke, fill, alpha (transparency). didn’t specify example, gf_point() uses default values – case smallish black filled-circles. gf_ functions, specify non-position graphical attributes using additional arguments function. Attributes can set constant value (e.g, set color “blue”; set size 2) can mapped variable data expression involving variables (e.g., map color sex, sex determines color groupings) Attributes set mapped using additional arguments. adding argument form attribute = value sets attribute value. adding argument form attribute = ~ expression maps attribute expression attribute one color, shape, etc., value constant (e.g. "red" 0.5, appropriate), expression may general expression can computed using variables data (although often better create new variable data use variable instead --fly calculation within plot). following plot, instance, use cyl determine color carb determine size dot. Color size mapped cyl carb. legend provided show us mapping done. (Later, can use scales control precisely mapping done – colors sizes used represent values cyl carb.) also set transparency 50%. gives value alpha glyphs layer.  ggformula allows --fly calculations attributes, although default labeling plot often better create new variable data frame. examples , since three values carb, easier read graph tell R treat cyl categorical variable converting factor (string). Except labeling legend, two plots . second example, see ggformula works well data tranformations using |>.

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: plots, specify x-position y-position calculated x-values. Histograms, densityplots, frequency polygons examples. illustrate, ’ll use density plots, ideas apply gf_histogram(), gf_freqpolygon() well. Note one-variable density graphics, variable whose density calculated goes right tilde, position reserved x-axis variable.     Several plotting functions include additional arguments modify attributes individual glyphs control aspect plot. case, adjust can used increase decrease amount smoothing.
code: data(penguins, package = "palmerpenguins")    gf_density( ~ bill_length_mm, data = penguins) gf_density( ~ bill_length_mm,  fill = ~ species,  alpha = 0.5, data = penguins) # gf_dens() is similar, but there is no line at bottom/sides and the plot is not fillable gf_dens( ~ bill_length_mm, color = ~ species,  alpha = 0.7, data = penguins) # gf_dens2() is like gf_dens() but is fillable gf_dens2( ~ bill_length_mm, fill = ~ species, data = penguins,           color = "gray50", alpha = 0.4) # less smoothing penguins |> gf_dens( ~ bill_length_mm, color = ~ species, alpha = 0.7, adjust = 0.25)   #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_density()`). # more smoothing penguins |> gf_dens( ~ bill_length_mm, color = ~ species, alpha = 0.7, adjust = 4)      #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_density()`).

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: fill color group aesthetics mapped variable, default behavior lay group-wise densities top one another. behavior also available using position argument. Using value "stack" causes densities laid one top another. makes overall height stack represent density across groups, can difficult discern shape distribution individual groups. value "fill" produces conditional probability graphic.   Similar commands can constructed gf_histogram() gf_freqpoly(), note color, fill, active attribute frequency polygons. ’s also rarely good overlay histograms top one another – better use density plot frequency polygon application.
code: penguins |>    gf_density( ~ bill_length_mm, fill = ~ species, color = NA, position = "stack") penguins |>    gf_density( ~ bill_length_mm, fill = ~ species, color = NA, position = "fill",                adjust = 2)

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)

code: penguins |>    gf_density_2d(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm) |>    gf_facet_grid( ~ species) # the dot here is a bit strange, but required to make a valid formula penguins |>    gf_density_2d(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm) |>    gf_facet_grid( species ~ .) penguins |>    gf_density_2d(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm) |>    gf_facet_grid(island ~ species) penguins |>    gf_density_2d_filled(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm,                         show.legend = FALSE) |>    gf_facet_wrap(island ~ species) Weather |>    gf_ribbon(low_temp + high_temp ~ date | city ~ year, alpha = 0.3) Weather |>    gf_linerange(low_temp + high_temp ~ date | city ~ year, color = ~ avg_temp) |>   gf_refine(scale_colour_gradientn(colors = rev(rainbow(5)))) Weather |>    gf_ribbon(low_temp + high_temp ~ date | city ~ ., alpha = 0.3) Weather |>    gf_linerange(low_temp + high_temp ~ date, color = ~ avg_temp) |>   gf_refine(scale_colour_gradientn(colors = rev(rainbow(5)))) |>   gf_facet_grid(city ~ year, scales = "free_x")

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: Usually plot labels reflect expression mapped given attribute. previous example, colorbar legend labeled “avg temp (F)” even though variable name avg_temp. Weather data set labeled. ggformula detect labels use plots. can use set_variable_labels() add custom labels variables data frame.1    adding labels data, can ensure consitent labeling across several plots. also possible modify labels just one plot. can done three ways: can use arguments like xlab, ylab, title; can use gf_labs() function (arguments like x, y, title, etc.); can use gf_relabel() function.     Notice gf_labs() gf_relabel() take different approaches labeling. gf_labs() refers labels role plot whereas gf_relabel() refers variables data set uses new labels wherever variable appears. useful. gf_labs() provides access additional labels (title, subtitle, caption, etc.), easier mistakenly create plot label doesn’t match true content plot. gf_relabel() deals labels associated variables, label guaranteed match variable matter variable used within plot.
code: get_variable_labels(Weather) #> $city #> NULL #>  #> $date #> NULL #>  #> $year #> NULL #>  #> $month #> NULL #>  #> $day #> NULL #>  #> $high_temp #> [1] "high temp (F)" #>  #> $avg_temp #> [1] "avg temp (F)" #>  #> $low_temp #> [1] "low temp (F)" #>  #> $high_dewpt #> [1] "high dew point (F)" #>  #> $avg_dewpt #> [1] "avg dew point (F)" #>  #> $low_dewpt #> [1] "low dew point (F)" #>  #> $high_humidity #> [1] "high relative humidity" #>  #> $avg_humidity #> [1] "avg relative humidity" #>  #> $low_humidity #> [1] "low relative humidity" #>  #> $high_hg #> [1] "high pressure (mm Hg)" #>  #> $avg_hg #> [1] "avg pressure (mm Hg)" #>  #> $low_hg #> [1] "low pressure (mm Hg)" #>  #> $high_vis #> [1] "high visibility (miles)" #>  #> $avg_vis #> [1] "avg visibility (miles)" #>  #> $low_vis #> [1] "low visibility (miles)" #>  #> $high_wind #> [1] "high wind speed (mph)" #>  #> $avg_wind #> [1] "avg wind speed (mph)" #>  #> $low_wind #> [1] "low wind speed (mph)" #>  #> $precip #> [1] "precipitation" #>  #> $events #> [1] "events" KF <- KidsFeet |>    set_variable_labels(     length = "length (cm)",      width = "width (cm)",     domhand = "dominant hand",     biggerfoot = "bigger foot"   )  KidsFeet |>    gf_point(width ~ length, color = ~domhand) KF |>   gf_point(width ~ length, color = ~domhand) Penguins <- penguins |>   set_variable_labels(     species = "Species",     island = "Island",     bill_length_mm = "Bill Length (mm)",     bill_depth_mm = "Bill Depth (mm)",     flipper_length_mm = "Flipper Length (mm)",     body_mass_g = "Body Mass (g)",     sex = "Sex"   )  Penguins |>   gf_point(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm, color = ~ species)  #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`). KidsFeet |>   gf_point(width ~ length, color = ~domhand, xlab = "length (cm)",             title = "Length and width of kids' feet") p <- KidsFeet |> gf_point(width ~ length, color = ~domhand)  p |>    gf_labs(x = "length (cm)", color = "dominant hand", title = "Some kids' feet") p |>    gf_relabel(length = "length (cm)", width = "width (cm)", domhand = "dominant hand") # alternatively, we can use a list.  # this is handy if we have several data sets with the same variables. KFlabels <-    list(length = "length (cm)", width = "width (cm)", domhand = "dominant hand") p |>    gf_relabel(KFlabels)

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: Sometimes many points scatter plot obscure one another. ggplot2 system provides two easy ways deal : translucency jittering. Use alpha make points semi-translucent. Using gf_jitter() place gf_point() move plotted points reduce overlap. Jitter transparency can used together well.    Box whisker plots show distribution quantitative variable function categorical variable. formula used gf_boxplot() quantitative variable left tilde. (make horizontal boxplots using ggplot2 make vertical boxplots flip coordinates coord_flip().)   plot may surprise .  single plot placed mean value month (city). warning message suggests need tell R form groups using quantitative variable x. suggests using group aesthetic, sometimes, just want.  Alternatively, create new categorical variable puts quantitative values one different bins. gf_violin() gf_sina() provide two alternatives box whisker plots. what: Plots with more than 2 positional attributes
title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: layers require two attributes. Typically happens glyphs layer complex objects made using multiple layers, belong together conceptually. Examples include gf_pointrange() – plots dot flanked line segment. gf_linrange() – like gf_pointrange() without point. gf_errorbar() – vertical error bars. gf_errorbarh() – horizontal error bars. gf_ribbon() – band line line . Often used depict sort estimate uncertainty measurement prediction, can used represent data correct form. use gf_linerange() gf_ribbon() indicate high low temperatures New York first months 2013.
code: Temps <-   Weather |>   filter(month <= 4, year <= 2016, city == "Chicago")  Temps |>    gf_pointrange(avg_temp + low_temp + high_temp  ~ date, color = ~ avg_temp) |>    gf_refine(scale_color_gradientn(colors = c("blue", "green", "orange", "red"))) Temps |>    gf_ribbon(low_temp + high_temp  ~ date, color = "navy", alpha = 0.3)

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: position_dodge(), position_jitter(), position_jitterdodge() can used adjust positions glyphs placed. Jittering adds random noise can useful many observations value. Dodging moves groups glyphs fixed difference make easier distinguish groups.  stat transformation applied data plot generated. Several plots seen made use stats. gf_histogram() uses stat_bin() bin data count number observations bin. equivalent  gf_boxplot() uses stat_boxplot() compute five-number summary boxplot based. gf_violin(), gf_density(), gf_density2d() use stats compute sequence points along estimated density. points, raw data used create plot. gf_sina() uses estimated density jitter points.   also number stats can used show functional relationship two variables. gf_smooth() plots model fit using lm(), glm(), gam(), loess(), MASS::rlm(). gf_lm() gf_smooth() method set lm() plots least squares regression line. gf_spline() plots spline fit data.    Confidence prediction bands can added well.  Mostly, stats selected default just ones need. sometimes useful select different stat. stat_summary() stat_summary_bin() stats particularly useful respect. stats use function aggregate unique values x bins x values save user needing data transformation manually. default function applied group mean_se(), computes mean (mean plus minus one standard error) makes simple create “interaction plot”.   two values computed mean_se() available (starting ggplot2 version 2.3) stat(ymin) stat(ymax).   Custom functions can used defining fun.y, fun.ymin, fun.ymax, single function fun.data returns data frame variables named y, ymin, ymax.  ggformula provides two way plot functions: gf_function() gf_fun(). differ primarily one specifies function plotted. gf_function() requires (vectorized) function one variable. gf_fun() requires formula describing y-values computed x-values. used first layer, limits x-axis must specified.
code: KidsFeet |>    gf_point(length ~ sex, color = ~ domhand,             position = position_jitterdodge(jitter.width = 0.2, dodge.width = 0.4)) HELPrct |> gf_bar( ~ age, stat = "bin") #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value `binwidth`. gf_boxplot(age ~ substance, data = HELPrct) gf_violin(age ~ substance, data = HELPrct) |>   gf_sina(alpha = 0.3) KidsFeet |>    gf_point(length ~ width, color = ~ sex) |>   gf_lm() mosaicData::Births |>     gf_point(births ~ date, color = ~wday, alpha = 0.15) |>   gf_smooth(method = "loess") mosaicData::Births |>     gf_point(births ~ date, color = ~wday, alpha = 0.15) |>   gf_spline(spar = 1) KidsFeet |>    gf_point(length ~ width | sex, color = ~ sex) |>   gf_lm(interval = "prediction", fill = "red") |>   gf_lm(interval = "confidence", fill = "navy") KidsFeet |>    gf_jitter(length ~ sex, color = ~ domhand, width = 0.1, height = 0) |>   gf_line(length ~ sex, color = ~ domhand, group = ~ domhand, stat = "summary") #> No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()` Penguins |>    gf_jitter(body_mass_g ~ sex, color = ~ species, width = 0.1, height = 0) |>   gf_line(body_mass_g ~ sex, color = ~ species, group = ~ species, stat = "summary") #> No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()` #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`). KidsFeet |>    gf_jitter(length ~ sex, color = ~ domhand, width = 0.1, height = 0, alpha = 0.5) |>   gf_pointrange(length + stat(ymin) + stat(ymax) ~ sex,                  color = ~ domhand, group = ~ domhand, stat="summary") #> No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()` Penguins |>    gf_jitter(body_mass_g ~ sex, color = ~ species, width = 0.1, height = 0, alpha = 0.3) |>   gf_pointrange(body_mass_g + stat(ymin) + stat(ymax) ~ sex, color = ~ species,                  group = ~ species, size = 1.5, stat="summary") #> No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()` #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_summary()`). #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`). KidsFeet |>    gf_point(length ~ sex, color = ~ domhand, width = 0.1, height = 0, alpha = 0.5,            position = position_jitterdodge(jitter.width = 0.2, dodge.width = 0.3)) |>   gf_pointrange(length + stat(ymin) + stat(ymax) ~ sex,                  color = ~ domhand, group = ~ domhand, stat="summary",                 fun.y = median, fun.ymin = min, fun.ymax = max,                 position = position_dodge(width = 0.6), size = 1.2) #> No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()` gf_function(fun = sqrt, xlim = c(0, 10)) |>   gf_fun(2 + 3 * cos(10 * x) ~ x, color = "red", n = 800) f <- makeFun(lm(totalbill ~ poly(month, 2), data = mosaicData::Utilities)) mosaicData::Utilities |>     gf_point(totalbill ~ month, alpha = 0.6) |>   gf_fun(f(m) ~ m, color = "red")

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: Prior ggplot2 version 2.3, basic maps created using gf_polygon().  Starting ggplot2 version 2.3, direct support shape files. allows row data frame contain geometry information region single column. also better support overlaying information multiple shape files.
code: if (require(maps) && require(dplyr)) {   US <- map_data("state") |>     dplyr::mutate(name_length = nchar(region))   States <- US |>     dplyr::group_by(region) |>     dplyr::summarise(lat = mean(range(lat)), long = mean(range(long))) |>     dplyr::mutate(name = abbreviate(region, 3))    gf_polygon(lat ~ long, data = US, group = ~ group,              fill = ~ name_length, color = "white") |>   gf_text(lat ~ long, label = ~ name, data = States,     color = "gray70", inherit = FALSE) |>   gf_refine(mosaic::theme_map()) } if (require(maps) && require(dplyr) && require(sf) && require(purrr)) {   USshape <-      sf::st_as_sf(maps::map('state', plot = FALSE, fill = TRUE)) |>     dplyr::mutate(       name_length = nchar(as.character(ID)),       centroid = purrr::map(geom, st_centroid),       coords_x = purrr::map_dbl(centroid, 1),       coords_y = purrr::map_dbl(centroid, 2)     )         gf_sf(fill = ~ factor(name_length), color = "white", data = USshape, alpha = 0.5) |>     gf_text(coords_y ~ coords_x, label = ~ ID, color = "gray20", size = 2) |>     gf_labs(x = "", y = "") |>     gf_refine(coord_sf()) |>     gf_theme(mosaic::theme_map()) |>     gf_labs(fill = "name length") } <!-- # gf_sf(data = sf::st_centroid(USshape), color = "white", alpha = 0.5, size = 3) |> -->

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: ggformula adds additional plot options ggplot2 Average shifted histograms can created gf_ash(). plots average height histograms bin width. ASH plots often work well larger bin widths might use individual histogram.   gf_dist() can used create plots discrete continuous distributions.      distribution parameters plot attributes name, two ways avoid name collision:   ggformula also provides interface MASS::fitdistr() fitting distributions data displaying resulting pdf.
code: HELPrct |>    gf_ash( ~ age, data = HELPrct, binwidth = 2) |>   gf_dhistogram( ~ age, binwidth = 2, alpha = 0.3) HELPrct |>    gf_ash( ~ age, binwidth = 10) |>    gf_dhistogram( ~ age, binwidth = 2, alpha = 0.3) gf_dist("pois", lambda = 5) gf_dist("pois", lambda = 5, kind = "cdf") gf_dist("gamma", shape = 3, rate = 4, geom = "area") gf_dist("gamma", shape = 3, rate = 4, geom = "area", fill = ~ (x <= 1)) gf_dist("gamma", shape = 3, rate = 4, kind = "cdf") # size is used by the binomial distribution functions and when plotting gf_dist("binom", size = 20, prob = 0.25, plot_size = 5) gf_dist("binom", params = list(size = 20, prob = 0.25), size = 3) x <- rgamma(1000, shape = 2, rate = 5) gf_dhistogram( ~ x, alpha = 0.3) |>   gf_fitdistr(dist = "dnorm", color = ~ "Normal") |>    gf_fitdistr(dist = "dgamma", color = ~ "Gamma") |>   gf_fitdistr(dist = "dweibull", color = ~ "Weibull") |>    gf_labs(color = "") #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value `binwidth`. #> Warning in densfun(x, parm[1], parm[2], ...): NaNs produced #> Warning in densfun(x, parm[1], parm[2], ...): NaNs produced #> Warning in densfun(x, parm[1], parm[2], ...): NaNs produced #> Warning in densfun(x, parm[1], parm[2], ...): NaNs produced #> Warning in densfun(x, parm[1], parm[2], ...): NaNs produced

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: number things may want entire plot – adjusting labels, colors, fonts, etc. ggformula provides wrappers ggplot2 functions chaining syntax can used.   convenience, modifications can also made directly original function call:
code: penguins |>    gf_histogram( ~ body_mass_g, alpha = 0.2, fill = "navy",               color = "gray50", binwidth = 200) |>   gf_freqpoly( ~ body_mass_g, binwidth = 200) |>   gf_facet_grid(species ~ .) |>    gf_labs(x = "bill length (mm)", title = "Palmer Penguins") |>   gf_lims(x = c(2500, 6500)) |>    gf_theme(theme = theme_minimal()) #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range (`stat_bin()`). #> Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range (`stat_bin()`). penguins |>    gf_histogram( ~ body_mass_g | species ~ ., alpha = 0.5, fill = "white",               binwidth = 200, color = "gray40") |>   gf_freqpoly( ~ body_mass_g, color = "skyblue",                 binwidth = 200, size = 1.2, alpha = 0.8) |>   gf_labs(x = "bill length (mm)", title = "Palmer Penguins") |>   gf_lims(x = c(2500, 6500)) |>    gf_theme(theme = theme_dark()) #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. #> Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range (`stat_bin()`). #> Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range (`stat_bin()`). #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the base package. #>   Please report the issue to the authors. penguins |>    gf_dhistogram( ~ body_mass_g | species ~ .,                  alpha = 0.5, fill = "skyblue", color = "navy", binwidth = 200,                  xlab = "body mass (g)", title = "Palmer Penguins"   )  #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range #> (`stat_bin()`).

title: Formula Interface for ggplot2 (full version)
text: geoms ggplot2 can either horizontal vertical direction. Often ggplot2 correctly determine orientation intended. , set orientation = 'x' orientation = 'y' explicitly set direction geom.
code: gf_boxplot(high_temp ~ city, data = Weather) # auto-detected because city is discrete gf_boxplot(city ~ high_temp, data = Weather) # auto-detected based on groups gf_boxplot(month ~ high_temp | ~ city, group = ~ month, data = Weather) gf_boxplot(high_temp ~ month | city ~ ., group = ~ month, data = Weather) # defaults to veritcal without groups  gf_boxplot(month ~ high_temp | ~ city, data = Weather) #> Warning: Continuous x aesthetic #> ℹ did you forget `aes(group = ...)`? # explicit horizontal orientation gf_boxplot(month ~ high_temp | city ~ ., data = Weather, orientation = 'y') #> Warning: Continuous y aesthetic #> ℹ did you forget `aes(group = ...)`?

title: Learn More About ggformula
text: Several text books either use ggformula accompanying documentation demonstrate use ggformula. Foundations Applications Statistics: Introduction Using R (R Pruim, second edition) R-infused probability mathematical statistics text emphasizes connections probability statistics. first edition book predates ggformula package, second edition supported fastR2 package uses ggformula plotting. https://bookstore.ams.org/amstext-28 www.ams.org/publications/authors/books/postpub/amstext-28 Introduction Practice Statistics R (NJ Horton BS Baumer) describes undertake analyses R introduced examples Introduction Practice Statistics, David Moore, George McCabe, Bruce Craig. 9th edition: nhorton.people.amherst.edu/ips9 Statistics: Unlocking Power Data (Lock, Lock, Lock, Lock, Lock) introductory statistics textbook embraces resampling approach. annotated companion examples book implemented using R can found github.com/rpruim/Lock5withR/ Lock5withR R package provides data sets used text. lock5stat.com Stats: Data Models (NJ Horton) describes undertake analyses R examples Fourth Edition Stats: Data Models (2015), Dick De Veaux, Paul Velleman, Dave Bock. nhorton.people.amherst.edu/sdm4 Intro Stats (P Frenett NJ Horton) describes undertake analyses R examples Fifth Edition Intro Stats (2013), Dick De Veaux, Paul Velleman, Dave Bock. 5th edition: nhorton.people.amherst.edu/is5 Open Intro Stats OpenIntro Stats now versions labs designed use mosaic package. mosaic labs adapted Ben Baumer Galen Long Smith College updated ggformula Bonnie Lin Nicholas Horton Amherst College.

code: @Manual{,   title = {ggformula: Formula Interface to the Grammar of Graphics},   author = {Daniel Kaplan and Randall Pruim},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.0.0},   url = {https://github.com/ProjectMOSAIC/ggformula}, }

title: Formula Interface to the Grammar of Graphics
text: ggformula introduces family graphics functions, gf_point(), gf_density(), , bring formula interface ggplot(). captures extends excellent simplicity lattice-graphics formula interface, providing intuitive “add component” capabilities ggplot2.

title: Formula Interface to the Grammar of Graphics
text: can install ggformula CRAN sith github :
code: install.packages("ggformula") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("ProjectMOSAIC/ggformula")

title: Formula Interface to the Grammar of Graphics
text: following example illustrates typical plot constructed ggformula.
code: suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(ggformula)) data(penguins, package = "palmerpenguins") penguins |>    tidyr::drop_na() |> # to avoid erros with default bandwidth calculation in stat_density_2d   set_variable_labels(     bill_length_mm = "bill length (mm)",     bill_depth_mm = "bill depth (mm)"   ) |>   gf_jitter(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm | island ~ sex, color = ~ species,           width = 0.05, height = 0.05, size = 0.5, alpha = 0.6) |>   gf_density2d(alpha = 0.3, bw = 1) |>   gf_labs(title = "Palmer Penguins",           caption = "Data available in palmerpenguins package"   ) |>   gf_refine(scale_color_brewer(type = "qual")) |>   gf_theme(theme_bw()) |>   gf_theme(     legend.position = 'top',     text = element_text(colour = "navy", face = "italic")   )
